indications:
Indications 
(From 8.1.1 Alkylating drugs: British National Formulary)
Chlorambucil is used either alone or in combination therapy for some lymphomas and chronic leukaemias. It is given by mouth. Side-effects, apart from bone-marrow suppression, are uncommon. However, patients occasionally develop severe widespread rashes which can progress to Stevens-Johnson syndrome or to toxic epidermal necrolysis. If a rash occurs further chlorambucil is contra-indicated and cyclophosphamide is substituted.
name: CHLORAMBUCIL
cautions:
Cautions see section 8.1 and notes above; history of epilepsy and children with nephrotic syndrome
(increased risk of seizures); avoid in acute
porphyria (but see section 9.8.2)
side-effects: Side-effects see section 8.1 and notes above
pregnancy:
Pregnancy avoid; manufacturer advises effective contraception
during treatment in men or women; see also Pregnancy and Reproductive
Function
